description: Point-of-view consistency rules governing perspective, psychic distance, and narrative voice in detective fiction

recommended_pov.primary: Third person limited (single or dual POV)
recommended_pov.justification: Detective procedurals benefit from mystery preservation through limited perspective while allowing intimate character access

alternatives.first_person: Strong voice intimacy but limits ability to show scenes without protagonist
alternatives.third_person_multiple: Allows showing antagonist perspective but risks diluting mystery tension

pov_consistency.description: Point of view must remain consistent within scenes; shifts must be clearly marked

validations.name: single-pov-per-scene
validations.description: Each scene must maintain single POV character perspective; no head-hopping mid-scene

examples.violation: Scene starts in detective's POV, suddenly reveals suspect's thoughts mid-paragraph, returns to detective
examples.compliant: Entire scene stays in detective's POV; suspect's thoughts shown only through observable behavior and dialogue

validations.validation_query: Whose perspective controls this entire scene from start to finish?

validations.name: pov-shift-signaling
validations.description: POV changes must be marked by scene breaks (### or clear white space)

examples.violation: POV shifts from detective to partner within continuous prose
examples.compliant: Detective POV scene ends, clear scene break (###), new scene begins in partner's POV

validations.validation_query: Is the POV shift marked with clear visual break for reader?

validations.name: pov-character-knowledge-limits
validations.description: Narration can only reveal information POV character knows/observes/deduces

examples.violation: Detective POV narration reveals killer's identity despite detective not knowing
examples.compliant: Detective observes suspect's nervous behavior and theorizes guilt, but narration doesn't confirm truth

validations.validation_query: How does the POV character know this information being narrated?

psychic_distance.description: Control intimacy level between reader and character; maintain consistency

levels.level_1_distant: Distant third person focusing on actions: 'The detective entered the room.'
levels.level_2_moderate: Moderate closeness with some internalization: 'She scanned the room, noting the overturned furniture.'
levels.level_3_close: Close third with thoughts: 'The scene didn't make sense. Why trash the place if this was a professional hit?'
levels.level_4_intimate: Deep POV with character voice coloring narration: 'Professional hit, her ass. Pros didn't throw temper tantrums.'

validations.name: distance-consistency
validations.description: Maintain relatively consistent psychic distance for each POV character; avoid jarring shifts

examples.violation: Paragraph 1: distant observation. Paragraph 2: deep intimate thoughts. Paragraph 3: back to distant.
examples.compliant: Detective POV consistently stays at level 3-4 (close to intimate) throughout scene

validations.validation_query: What psychic distance level is this scene maintaining? Are there inconsistent jumps?

validations.name: tension-distance-correlation
validations.description: Increase intimacy (closer distance) during high-emotion moments; can pull back for action

examples.violation: Emotional breakthrough moment described in distant third person
examples.compliant: Emotional scenes: intimate distance showing internal reaction. Action scenes: moderate distance focusing on physical events.

validations.validation_query: Does the psychic distance match the emotional intensity of this moment?

sensory_filtering.description: All sensory description must be filtered through POV character's perception

validations.name: character-filtered-description
validations.description: Descriptions should reflect POV character's observational priorities and biases

examples.violation: Detective enters room, narration provides objective architectural description irrelevant to character
examples.compliant: Detective enters room, immediately notes security camera placement and exit routes (professional POV filter)

validations.validation_query: Why would this POV character notice and describe these specific details?

validations.name: emotional-coloring
validations.description: Descriptions should be colored by character's emotional state when appropriate

examples.violation: Grieving character describes environment in neutral, cheerful terms
examples.compliant: Grieving character sees surroundings as muted, notices objects connected to loss, describes setting with melancholic word choice

validations.validation_query: Does the descriptive language reflect the character's current emotional state?

validations.name: professional-perspective
validations.description: Detective POV should notice details relevant to investigation; civilians notice different things

examples.violation: Experienced detective overlooks obvious evidence in crime scene description
examples.compliant: Detective notices: blood spatter pattern, defensive wounds, missing items, while civilian witness focuses on emotional impact

validations.validation_query: Does this character's observation pattern match their profession and experience?

internal_monologue.description: Character thoughts must be authentic to personality and situation

validations.name: thought-voice-consistency
validations.description: Internal thoughts should match character's established speaking voice and personality

examples.violation: Street-smart detective's thoughts use formal academic language inconsistent with dialogue
examples.compliant: Detective's internal voice matches their dialogue style: same vocabulary, sentence structure, humor

validations.validation_query: Would this character think in these words, or are they thinking in author's voice?

validations.name: natural-thought-flow
validations.description: Thoughts should be realistic: associative, sometimes fragmented, not perfectly organized speeches

examples.violation: Character's thoughts are perfectly structured arguments with topic sentences and conclusions
examples.compliant: Thoughts jump between observations, memories, questions, reactions—mimicking actual thinking patterns

validations.validation_query: Do these thoughts sound like natural thinking or like written analysis?

validations.name: no-self-evident-thoughts
validations.description: Characters don't think about things they already know unless processing/questioning

examples.violation: 'I'm a detective with twenty years of experience,' she thought
examples.compliant: 'Twenty years on the job and this case still doesn't make sense'

validations.validation_query: Why would this character be thinking this at this moment? What triggers it?

observation_limits.description: POV character cannot observe what they cannot see/hear/sense

validations.name: physical-observation-constraints
validations.description: Character can only observe what's physically possible from their position

examples.violation: Detective in interrogation room describes what suspect is doing in holding cell down the hall
examples.compliant: Detective observes only what's visible in current location; learns about other locations through reports/cameras/witnesses

validations.validation_query: Can the POV character actually see/hear/perceive this from their current position?

validations.name: magical-perception-consistency
validations.description: If character has magical senses, their range and limits must be consistent

examples.violation: Character detects magic within 50ft in Ch 3, suddenly senses magic miles away in Ch 8 with no explanation
examples.compliant: Character's magical perception has consistent range; extended perception requires specific ritual or effort with cost

validations.validation_query: Is this magical observation consistent with previously established sensory limits?

validations.name: no-mind-reading
validations.description: POV character cannot know other characters' thoughts unless they have established telepathy

examples.violation: Detective knows suspect is lying because narration says 'The suspect was lying'
examples.compliant: Detective suspects lying based on observable tells: 'His eyes shifted left. The classic tell.'

validations.validation_query: Is this presented as POV character's deduction or as omniscient fact?

multiple_pov_management.description: When using multiple POV characters, maintain clear rules and purpose

validations.name: limited-pov-cast
validations.description: Limit POV characters to 2-3 maximum for procedural; typically protagonist detective + 1-2 others

examples.violation: Story uses 6+ POV characters, diluting focus and mystery
examples.compliant: Primary detective POV (80% of scenes) + antagonist POV (15%, to show threat) + partner POV (5%, when separated)

validations.validation_query: How many POV characters are there? Does each serve clear narrative purpose?

validations.name: pov-distribution-balance
validations.description: Maintain clear primary POV; secondary POVs should be significantly less frequent

examples.violation: Three POV characters each get equal page time, no clear protagonist
examples.compliant: Detective POV: 70-80% of scenes. Partner POV: 15-20%. Antagonist POV: 5-10%

validations.validation_query: What is the POV distribution? Is there a clear primary perspective?

validations.name: antagonist-pov-mystery-preservation
validations.description: If using antagonist POV, must preserve mystery without revealing identity or full plan

examples.violation: Antagonist POV reveals their identity, complete plan, and timeline—eliminating mystery
examples.compliant: Antagonist POV shows menace and methods without revealing identity (unnamed, no mirrors) or full scheme

validations.validation_query: Does this antagonist POV maintain mystery tension or spoil the investigation?

narrative_voice.description: Narrative voice must be consistent and appropriate to POV style

validations.name: voice-pov-alignment
validations.description: Third person limited should use more neutral voice than deep POV; deep POV uses character's voice

examples.violation: Third limited suddenly uses heavy character slang in narration inconsistently
examples.compliant: Deep POV: 'The perp was a ghost. No prints, no trace, no nothing.' vs Third limited: 'The suspect had left no evidence.'

validations.validation_query: Does the narrative voice match the intended POV intimacy level?

validations.name: tense-consistency
validations.description: Maintain consistent past or present tense throughout; no random shifts

examples.violation: Past tense narration suddenly shifts to present tense mid-scene without stylistic purpose
examples.compliant: Entire manuscript in consistent past tense

validations.validation_query: Is the narrative tense consistent throughout this section?

agent_integration.finn: Primary validator for POV consistency and narrative voice
agent_integration.tessa: Check for POV violations, head-hopping, and knowledge inconsistencies
agent_integration.bailey: Monitor POV during drafting; ensure sensory filtering appropriate to character
agent_integration.dr_viktor: Validate internal monologue authenticity and thought-voice consistency
